comments:
Following the basic hello world walkthrough:
Open Java Perspective
Create new Java project (just accepting all defaults, calling project "Hello")
Within the project, create a new public class ("Hello") - check box for main() constructor to be created, leave box checked to inherit methods from abstract classes
Click finish, it does creates an empty .java file and then pops up a thrown exception window:
Creation of element failed. org.eclipse.core.internal.utils.UniversalUniqueIdentifier
This has never failed to happen to me.

From the .log file, this is what I get:

What VM are you using? Please provide output of "java -version" and VM vendor if you know it (Sun/IBM/GCJ, etc).

Did you unzip Eclipse on top of an older Eclipse install?

java version "1.4.2"
gij (GNU libgcj) version 4.1.1 20070105 (Red Hat 4.1.1-51)

Eclipse had been previously installed before an upgrade (rather than new install) from FC4 to FC6. I found it wasn't working, so I used rpm to uninstall, then I used yum to install, figuring maybe there was maybe a bug in the version that shipped with FC6, and that the latest available rpm might work.
Andrew, any ideas? I haven't seen this before, although it has some similarity to bug 140064 (involving loading the UniversalUniqueIdentifer class, which uses java.net.InetAdress.

(In reply to comment #4)
> Andrew, any ideas?

Not OTTOMH but this should really be filed at bugzilla.redhat.com and closed as FEDORA until we can figure out where the problem lies.  Since there is no really appropriate resolution, let's mark it as WORKSFORME after it's filed at b.r.c and the link is noted here.

Thanks Andrew.

Sir Christopher, can you please log a bug at bugzilla.redhat.com?  One thing you could try to verify the problem is run Eclipse with another VM such as Sun, and see if the problem still occurs.

FWIW, I just tried this with the same version of gcj that the reporter has and it worked fine.  I get nothing in the log.

I'm wondering if something odd is in ~/.eclipse or the workspace.
I'm going to punt this over to Linux Distros to do a bit more investigation.  I'll also re-open.

This looks like this bug:

https://bugzilla.redhat.com/bugzilla/show_bug.cgi?id=178156

So this is definitely a Fedora problem and should be filed there. I can't reproduce this problem either so I'm going to close it again. If you want us to debug this problem please re-open the Fedora bug listed above. Thanks, Ben
